A14_EconomicSector.most_frequent: Code: 8411, Description: General public administration activities, Level: 4

A50_CaseSummary.most_frequent: Datatilsynet fined SATS ASA NOK 10 million after complaints revealed mishandled access/erasure requests, opaque retention/legal bases, and unlawful processing of training history data. The DPA found breaches of Articles 5, 6, 12, 13, 15 and 17, noted systemic negligence, and acted as lead authority for cross-border processing. Although SATS took some remedial steps during the investigation, the fine was set after a detailed Art. 83(2) assessment to ensure deterrence.

export_info.description: Initial cleaned and processed GDPR enforcement dataset

data.A14_EconomicSector: Code: 9311, Description: Operation of sports facilities, Level: 4
data.A50_CaseSummary: Datatilsynet fined SATS ASA NOK 10 million after complaints revealed mishandled access/erasure requests, opaque retention/legal bases, and unlawful processing of training history data. The DPA found breaches of Articles 5, 6, 12, 13, 15 and 17, noted systemic negligence, and acted as lead authority for cross-border processing. Although SATS took some remedial steps during the investigation, the fine was set after a detailed Art. 83(2) assessment to ensure deterrence.

The Norwegian DPA decided that health personnel should be able to reserve themselves from being rated on Legelisten.no and ordered deletion of email addresses of users who reviewed specialist health service personnel. It found the balance between freedom of expression and privacy inadequate, citing risks of misuse and harm to doctors and their families. Legelisten.no will appeal, and the reservation right will not take effect until the Privacy Board rules.

data.A14_EconomicSector: Code: 9491, Description: Activities of religious organizations, Level: 4
data.A50_CaseSummary: The Privacy Board reviewed an appeal by X Mission Assembly against a reprimand for storing and using neighbor’s private camera recordings depicting a board member. The Board majority held that the Mission Assembly had a legitimate interest under Article 6(1)(f) to store and view the footage and that the intrusion was limited, reversing the reprimand. A minority would have upheld the DPA’s view that the processing was unnecessary and unlawful.

data.A14_EconomicSector: Code: 8411, Description: General public administration activities, Level: 4
data.A50_CaseSummary: Bergen municipality exposed credentials, allowing access to school systems for over 35,000 users, including children. The DPA found violations of Art. 5(1)(f) and Art. 32(1)(a)-(b), noting lack of two-factor authentication and poor security practices, and ordered implementation of strong authentication for employees. A fine of NOK 1,600,000 was imposed after a systematic Art. 83 assessment, considering children’s special protection and prior related findings.

data.A14_EconomicSector: Code: 8411, Description: General public administration activities, Level: 4
data.A26_InfringementDuration: Until 06-09-2018; closed the same day it was discovered
data.A50_CaseSummary: The Norwegian DPA fined Oslo Municipality 1.2 million NOK after serious security flaws in the Skolemelding app allowed unauthorized access to data on over 63,000 primary school children, including potential health details entered via free-text fields. The DPA found violations of Art. 5(1)(f), Art. 5(2) and Art. 32(1)(b),(d), citing inadequate testing, authentication flaws, and lack of supplier control. Mitigating measures taken promptly after discovery led to a reduced fine from the initially notified amount.

data.A14_EconomicSector: Code: 8411, Description: General public administration activities, Level: 4
data.A50_CaseSummary: A complaint revealed that the Norwegian Public Roads Administration retained toll passage data in the invoice module of CS Norge beyond the lawful bookkeeping period, failing to delete tag number, location, and time. The DPA found violations of GDPR Art. 5(1)(a) and Art. 17(1)(a),(d), noted gross negligence, and ordered deletion while imposing a NOK 1,000,000 fine. Article 25 was not applied due to system phase-out; the DPA recognized joint controllership with Fjellinjen and identified Q-Free as a processor.

data.A14_EconomicSector: Code: 8411, Description: General public administration activities, Level: 4
data.A32_RightsInvolved: Access, Rectification, Erasure, Portability, Objection, Restrict_Processing, Automated_Decision_Making
data.A50_CaseSummary: A complaint challenged the Norwegian DPA’s processing on its website and complaint-handling practices. The set director found Art. 6(1)(f) a valid basis, no breach of Art. 5 or Art. 57, but a past breach of Art. 13(1)(d) and a breach of Art. 77(1) where complainants were required to contact controllers first for rights cases. The DPA had already rectified transparency issues and was expected to adjust complaint procedures accordingly.

data.A14_EconomicSector: Code: 8411, Description: General public administration activities, Level: 4
data.A50_CaseSummary: Asker municipality published document titles on its website revealing 127 national ID numbers and confidential details, including matters involving children, across 2004–2020. The DPA found violations of GDPR Articles 6, 32(1)(b), and 24, noted gross negligence and inadequate security measures, and highlighted at least 120 affected individuals. A fine of NOK 1,000,000 was imposed, with emphasis on the long duration and seriousness of the breach.

data.A11_DefendantName: Norwegian Sports Confederation and the Olympic and Paralympic Committee
data.A50_CaseSummary: NIF tested a cloud solution using real data from 3.2 million individuals, including 486,447 children, exposing it publicly for 87 days due to inadequate security and lack of risk assessment. The DPA found violations of GDPR Art. 5(1)(a),(c),(f), Art. 6, and Art. 32, noting no valid legal basis and insufficient technical and organizational measures. A NOK 2,500,000 fine was proposed after a systematic Art. 83(2) assessment, with mitigation due to limited evidence of harm.

The Norwegian DPA fined Dragefossen AS NOK 150,000 for operating a public-space webcam and live-streaming it online without a valid legal basis, violating Art. 6(1) and the lawfulness principle in Art. 5(1)(a). It found individuals were identifiable and any legitimate interests were outweighed, noting wide coverage, a 12-hour rewind, and impact on many residents including children. Dragefossen ended the stream after a warning; cooperation was noted but routines were inadequate, and the fine was set following Art. 83(2) factors.

data.A14_EconomicSector: Code: 9602, Description: Hairdressing and other beauty treatment, Level: 4
data.A50_CaseSummary: The Data Inspectorate fined Waxing Palace AS NOK 100,000 for unlawful camera surveillance in the salon’s reception area. The authority found no legal basis for the CCTV and inadequate transparency about the monitoring, affecting both employees and customers. The fee reflected the seriousness of the breach and the company’s finances, with an appeal deadline of 20 August 2021.

The Norwegian DPA fined Ferde AS NOK 5,000,000 for lacking a data processor agreement, documented risk assessment, and a valid transfer mechanism when transferring toll images to China between 2017 and 2019. Initiated ex officio after media reports, the DPA found violations of Art. 28(3), Art. 32(2) with Art. 5(1)(f) and 5(2), and Art. 44, noting significant processing volumes, negligence attributable to the board, and no proven harm. Later remedial measures did not mitigate the fine.

data.A14_EconomicSector: Code: 8530, Description: Tertiary education, Level: 4
data.A50_CaseSummary: NTNU accessed an employee’s university email without meeting the email regulation’s conditions, and the DPA found no legal basis under the data protection regulation. An initial notice proposed a NOK 150,000 infringement fee, but the final decision confirmed the breach while dropping the fee due to mitigating circumstances submitted by NTNU. Other complaints by the employee were assessed with no breach found.

data.A11_DefendantName: The Church of Norway by the Council of Churches
data.A14_EconomicSector: Code: 9491, Description: Activities of religious organizations, Level: 4
data.A26_InfringementDuration: 1 October 2018 to 14 November 2018, with continued storage until 18 August 2020
data.A50_CaseSummary: The DPA reprimanded the Church of Norway for unlawfully obtaining and storing birth notifications of members’ children from the Population Register between 1 October and 14 November 2018 without a valid Article 6 basis. It also found violations of Articles 14(1)(d), 14(2)(f), and 12(1) for failing to provide easily accessible information about categories and the source of data. DNK ceased intake on 14 November 2018 and deleted the data on 18 August 2020; no fine was imposed.

data.A14_EconomicSector: Code: 4520, Description: Maintenance and repair of motor vehicles, Level: 4
data.A50_CaseSummary: The Norwegian DPA fined Miljø- og Kvalitetsledelse AS EUR 3,500 for unlawfully disclosing CCTV footage and data to the employer of a suspected vandal. The DPA found violations of GDPR Articles 6(1) and 5(1)(a) because disclosure was unnecessary, noting the footage had already been given to the police; the infringement occurred before 20 July 2018 and the fine level followed previous legislation.

data.A14_EconomicSector: Code: 47, Description: Retail trade, except of motor vehicles and motorcycles, Level: 2
data.A50_CaseSummary: The Norwegian DPA fined Coop Finnmark SA NOK 400,000 for unlawfully disclosing CCTV footage of children by filming and sharing it via a private phone, breaching Art. 6 and Art. 5(1)(a). Legitimate interest under Art. 6(1)(f) was rejected given the availability of reporting to police and the special protection for children, with gross negligence attributed to the store manager. Mitigating actions included apologies and deletion requests, but the fine reflected seriousness, potential harm, and the company’s finances.

The Norwegian DPA reprimanded Disqus Inc. for disclosing Norwegian users’ personal data in real time to parent company Zeta Global without a valid legal basis, breaching GDPR Art. 6(1) and the lawfulness principle in Art. 5(1)(a). The case stemmed from media reports about Disqus deploying a non-EEA version of its widget on Norwegian sites (2018–2019); the DPA limited its assessment to subsequent processing and found claimed consent invalid under GDPR. Given evidentiary limitations, immediate deletion of data, and long processing time, the DPA issued a reprimand instead of the initially notified fine.

data.A14_EconomicSector: Code: 8610, Description: Hospital activities, Level: 4
data.A50_CaseSummary: A Norwegian hospital reported three security deviations where patient health data, including cardiology and child psychiatry information, was improperly accessible and insufficiently logged over several years. The DPA found negligent failures in access control and logging, concluding violations of GDPR Articles 32 and 24 (with references to Article 5), and imposed a NOK 750,000 fine after assessing Article 83(2) factors. Mitigating measures implemented by the hospital and self-reporting were considered but did not negate the seriousness and duration of the breaches.

data.A14_EconomicSector: Code: 6530, Description: Pension funding, Level: 4
data.A50_CaseSummary: The DPA issued an advance notice of reprimand to Bodø Kommunale Pensjonskasse for compiling identifiable health-related statistics and disclosing sensitive data to Bodø Municipality without a valid legal basis under Articles 6 and 9 GDPR. It evaluated data minimization regarding medical certificates (no clear breach found) but found the statistics and disclosure incompatible with GDPR. BKP had adjusted practices in 2017 and 2018, and the case was handled under the new law leading to a milder reaction.

data.A14_EconomicSector: Code: 6530, Description: Pension funding, Level: 4
data.A50_CaseSummary: The DPA initiated an investigation based on a whistleblower notification about Bodø Kommunale Pensjonskasse’s handling of health data, including obtaining medical certificates, compiling identifiable statistics, and sharing them with Bodø Municipality. It found violations of GDPR Articles 6 and 9 for compiling non-anonymised health-related statistics and disclosing sensitive data to the municipality without a valid legal basis, and issued an advance notice of reprimand. BKP had previously adjusted certain practices (e.g., reduced medical certificate collection in 2017 and board reporting changes in 2018).

data.A14_EconomicSector: Code: 6419, Description: Other monetary intermediation, Level: 4
data.A50_CaseSummary: Sbanken appealed a Datatilsynet order to correct a customer’s name capitalization (“van”). The Privacy Board held that capitalization differences do not make the data “incorrect” under GDPR Art. 16, considering purpose and varying naming conventions, and that identification risk was unaffected. It reversed the order, finding no infringement.

data.A14_EconomicSector: Code: 8411, Description: General public administration activities, Level: 4
data.A50_CaseSummary: The Norwegian DPA fined Høylandet municipality NOK 400,000 for inadequate security under Articles 32 and 24 after employees could access health data of individuals unconnected to the municipality due to a misconfigured script in a vendor system. The municipality failed to take adequate measures for about 11 months, with negligence and partly intentional conduct noted; no concrete harm was known, and self-reporting was considered. Special category (health) data was involved, and measures were implemented only after the DPA’s notice.

data.A14_EconomicSector: Code: 8430, Description: Compulsory social security activities, Level: 4
data.A50_CaseSummary: Datatilsynet fined the Government Pension Fund (SPK) NOK 1,000,000 for unlawfully collecting and retaining unnecessary income data, including health-related disability pension information, for post-settlement. It found violations of GDPR Art. 5(1)(c) and (e) and the necessity requirement in Art. 6(1) (cf. Art. 9(2)), affecting about 44,000 individuals from October 2016 to October 2019, while finding no breach of confidentiality. Mitigating factors included self-reporting and remedial measures (blocking, deletion, filters), and the DPA applied Art. 83(2) factors to set the fine.

The Norwegian DPA fined Gveik AS NOK 75,000 and ordered it to implement internal controls after a curiosity-driven credit check lacked a legal basis under Article 6 and breached Article 5(2). The DPA found the processing intrusive and organizational measures inadequate, assessing factors under Article 83(2). No special-category data were involved; cooperation and limited impact mildly mitigated, but absence of legitimate interest and routines warranted sanctions.

The Norwegian DPA fined an unnamed company NOK 250,000 for unlawful automatic forwarding and monitoring of an employee’s email without a legal basis. It cited violations of national rules on employer access to email and GDPR legal basis requirements, and ordered improvements to internal control and guidelines. The company has three weeks to appeal.

data.A14_EconomicSector: Code: 8411, Description: General public administration activities, Level: 4
data.A50_CaseSummary: Arendal municipality appealed the DPA’s ban and deletion order regarding the non-anonymous school mapping tool Spekter. The Privacy Board found a valid legal basis under GDPR Art. 6(1)(c) with the Education Act ch. 9A, but identified violations related to transparency (Art. 12), missing records (Art. 30), lack of risk assessment (Art. 32(2)) and DPIA (Art. 35(7)). It stated that future lawful use requires establishing internal control documentation and routines to safeguard data subjects’ rights and information security.

data.A14_EconomicSector: Code: 8411, Description: General public administration activities, Level: 4
data.A26_InfringementDuration: from Friday 27 September to Monday 30 September
data.A50_CaseSummary: The Norwegian DPA fined Indre Østfold municipality NOK 200,000 for breaching confidentiality by publishing a former student’s file on its website. The file contained confidential personal data and was online from Friday 27 September to Monday 30 September before removal after a journalist alerted the municipality; the data subject was notified. Subsequent remedial measures were considered but did not affect the fine amount.

The Norwegian Data Protection Authority fined Innovation Norway NOK 1,000,000 for conducting credit assessments without a valid legal basis or any relevant relationship to the complainant. The DPA emphasized that credit information on a sole proprietorship is personal data about the owner and requires a lawful processing basis; repeated checks were perceived as offensive, and the fine amount remained unchanged from the prior notice. Innovation Norway has a three-week appeal period.

Norway’s DPA fined Krokatjønnveien 15 AS NOK 300,000 for conducting two credit assessments without a legal basis, following complaints from two individuals. The DPA found no legitimate interest justified the processing of sensitive financial information in the credit checks. The company was also ordered to establish written routines for credit assessments.

data.A14_EconomicSector: Code: 6312, Description: Web portals, Level: 4
data.A50_CaseSummary: The NO DPA issued an advance notification to fine Grindr for unlawfully sharing user data with advertising partners based on invalid consent and for disclosing special category data concerning sexual orientation. It found consent was not freely given, specific, informed, or unambiguous, and that Article 9(1) was breached, considering aggravating factors including scope, duration, and sensitivity of data. A fine of NOK 100 million was deemed effective, proportionate, and dissuasive.

data.A14_EconomicSector: Code: 6120, Description: Wireless telecommunications activities, Level: 4
data.A50_CaseSummary: The Norwegian Data Inspectorate issued a notice of reprimand to Telenor Norge AS for inadequate security in its voicemail function and failure to notify a personal data breach under GDPR Article 33. The vulnerability allowed voicemail interception via spoofing services for several years, affecting about 1.3 million Norwegian mobile subscribers, constituting a violation of Article 32(1). Considering NKOM had already imposed a separate fine under telecom law, the DPA opted for a reprimand under Article 58(2)(b) to avoid double punishment.

data.A14_EconomicSector: Code: 53, Description: Postal and courier activities, Level: 2
data.A26_InfringementDuration: 31 March 2017 to 21 February 2020; and 8 August 2019 to 6 March 2020
data.A50_CaseSummary: The Norwegian DPA ordered PostNord AS to implement suitable technical measures for the “mypostnord” service after two breach notifications revealed unauthorized access to customer profiles via reassigned or mistyped phone numbers. The DPA found an infringement of Article 32 for inadequate measures ensuring confidentiality and required remediation under Article 58(2)(d); PostNord accepted and planned to introduce two-factor authentication. No fine was imposed.

data.A14_EconomicSector: Code: 8411, Description: General public administration activities, Level: 4
data.A50_CaseSummary: Ålesund Municipality required students to use Strava on their private phones for PE classes, using tracking to verify task completion. The DPA found failures to implement appropriate measures, conduct a risk assessment, and perform a DPIA, violating Art. 24(1), Art. 32(1)(b) and Art. 35, and imposed a NOK 50,000 fine. The decision cited gross negligence, risks from exposure of names and location data, and noted prompt remedial measures as mitigating.

The DPA fined Cyberbook AS NOK 200,000 for illegally auto-forwarding a former employee’s email for several months without informing them. It found violations of rules on employer access to email, lack of legal basis, failure to inform the data subject, failure to assess objections, and breaches of deletion rules. The DPA ordered Cyberbook to establish written routines for access to current and former employees’ email boxes.

data.A14_EconomicSector: Code: 8411, Description: General public administration activities, Level: 4
data.A50_CaseSummary: The Norwegian DPA fined Moss municipality NOK 500,000 for inadequate technical and organizational measures during an IT system conversion that caused health data errors and unauthorized access, violating GDPR Art. 32(1)(b) and (d). Around 2,000 people were potentially affected; lack of risk assessment and insufficient testing were key failings, though the municipality notified the DPA and later implemented preventive measures. No prior violations or financial benefit were found, and the DPA applied Art. 83 factors in setting the fine.

The Norwegian DPA fined an unnamed company NOK 400,000 and ordered improved routines after it automatically forwarded an employee’s mailbox during sick leave for over a month. It found violations of rules on employer access, lack of legal basis, inadequate information to the data subject, and failure to assess the employee’s protest. The company has appealed.

data.A14_EconomicSector: Code: 8411, Description: General public administration activities, Level: 4
data.A50_CaseSummary: A Norwegian municipality used the Showbie app for communicating children’s health data without adequate security, lacking two-factor authentication, risk assessment, and a required DPIA. The DPA found violations of Art. 32(1)(b) and (d), Art. 24, Art. 35, and Art. 5(1)(f) and 5(2), noting high risk to children’s rights though no actual damage was established. An administrative fine of NOK 500,000 was imposed, with timely deletion considered a mitigating factor.

The Norwegian Data Inspectorate notified Odin Flissenter AS of an order and a NOK 300,000 violation fee for credit rating a single-person enterprise without a valid legal basis. The DPA emphasized that credit information about individual companies constitutes personal data linked to the owner’s personal finances and requires a lawful basis. It stressed such data should not be collected by businesses unless objectively justified.

The Norwegian DPA fined Aquateknikk AS for unlawfully obtaining a competitor’s personal credit information without a valid legal basis and ordered improved internal controls under Art. 24. The DPA rejected arguments for Art. 6(1)(e) and found Art. 6(1)(f) not met, stressing the intrusiveness of credit data and negligence by management. A NOK 100,000 fine and a compliance order were imposed, considering Article 83 factors and the company’s financial situation.

data.A14_EconomicSector: Code: 6010, Description: Radio broadcasting, Level: 4
data.A26_InfringementDuration: 6 weeks of daily access; mailbox kept open until January 2020
data.A50_CaseSummary: The Norwegian DPA found that Radio Grenland unlawfully accessed a former employee’s email, failed to inform, kept the mailbox open, and did not delete contents, violating Articles 6(1)(f), 13, 17(1)(e), 21, and 24. The DPA applied Norway’s email access regulations, found the access disproportionate and continued despite objection, and noted inadequate organizational measures. A NOK 150,000 fine and an order to establish written routines were imposed.

data.A14_EconomicSector: Code: 8610, Description: Hospital activities, Level: 4
data.A50_CaseSummary: The Norwegian DPA fined Østfold HF Hospital NOK 750,000 and ordered improvements after unsecured storage of EHR report extracts left sensitive patient data accessible to 118 employees from 2013–2019. It found violations of GDPR Articles 32, 24, 5(1)(f), 5(1)(e), 5(2), 25, and 30, and related Patient Records Act provisions, citing inadequate access control, lack of logging, poor internal control, and excessive retention. The DPA deemed patient notification under Article 34 unnecessary but required strengthening of the management system, especially access control and storage routines.

A company automatically forwarded all emails from a former employee’s mailbox to the general manager for about six weeks, handling both work and private emails. The DPA found no legal basis and breaches of information duties under the GDPR, as well as violations of national rules on employer access to email, and noted inadequate routines. It imposed a NOK 100,000 fine and ordered the company to improve written routines.

data.A14_EconomicSector: Code: C, Description: Manufacturing, Level: 1
data.A50_CaseSummary: The Norwegian DPA fined Ultra-Technology AS NOK 125,000 for conducting a credit assessment without a legal basis and ordered it to establish written routines under Article 24. The DPA found the company, as controller, lacked legitimate interest; the unlawful credit check was performed intentionally by the general manager on one individual, involving sensitive credit data in a single incident. The fine was reduced due to lengthy case processing time.

data.A14_EconomicSector: Code: 6419, Description: Other monetary intermediation, Level: 4
data.A50_CaseSummary: The Norwegian DPA fined BRABANK ASA 400000 NOK for violating Articles 24 and 32 after a faulty launch of "My Page" let customers view other customers’ loan and some contact information. About 91 users logged in during the 10-minute breach, but the DPA considered 500 customers affected; the bank shut the service immediately and implemented fixes, yet negligence was found. No special category data was involved; EDPB fine guidelines and Art. 83(2) factors were applied.

A appealed the DPA’s finding that Bergens Tidende’s collection and publication of his credit information in 2019 fell under the journalistic exemption in Section 3 of the Personal Data Act. The Privacy Board held that this processing was exclusively for journalistic purposes and thus largely exempt from GDPR rules, noting that core editorial reporting does not trigger a proportionality balancing by privacy authorities. The Board upheld the DPA’s decision and dismissed the complaint.

data.A14_EconomicSector: Code: O, Description: Public administration and defense; compulsory social security, Level: 1
data.A50_CaseSummary: The Norwegian DPA fined the Labour Inspection Authority NOK 150,000 for an intentional, unlawful credit assessment lacking a valid national legal basis under Art. 6(1)(e) and (3). The DPA found inadequate organizational measures, assessed Art. 83(2) factors, and noted no special-category data or cross-border elements. Updated routines were considered, while a separate reprimand addressed a violation of the right of access.

The Norwegian DPA fined Trumf AS NOK 5,000,000 for failing to implement appropriate security (Art. 32) and for repeatedly failing to document and notify personal data breaches (Art. 33(1) and 33(5)). A long-standing lack of bank account ownership verification in a loyalty program enabled unauthorized access to detailed purchase histories, posing risks including to vulnerable persons. The DPA found Trumf knew of incidents since 2018, did not report them within 72 hours, and should have restricted data or implemented verification sooner, though later mitigation and cooperation were noted.

data.A11_DefendantName: The Norwegian Prison and Probation Service
data.A14_EconomicSector: Code: 8423, Description: Public order and safety activities, Level: 4
data.A50_CaseSummary: The DPA, acting ex officio, ordered the Norwegian Prison and Probation Service to establish a full processing overview, clarify allocation of controller responsibilities, and submit documented internal control due to an inadequate Article 30 protocol and lack of responsibility documentation. Relying on GDPR Article 58(2) and national provisions, the DPA noted the processing includes very sensitive and special category data and set a deadline of 21 September 2021. No fine was imposed, though a coercive fine may follow for non-compliance.

data.A14_EconomicSector: Code: 8411, Description: General public administration activities, Level: 4
data.A26_InfringementDuration: Occurred on 2 September 2020; duration not specified
data.A50_CaseSummary: The Norwegian DPA fined the Storting NOK 2,000,000 after a September 2020 breach exposed email accounts due to lack of two-factor authentication. It found violations of GDPR Art. 32(1)(b),(d) and Art. 5(1)(f), noting health data could have been compromised and that the director acted with gross negligence. Post-incident measures (password rules, logging, training, and MFA rollout) were considered but did not prevent the sanction.

data.A14_EconomicSector: Code: 61, Description: Telecommunications, Level: 2
data.A50_CaseSummary: The Norwegian DPA, acting as lead authority, found that Telenor’s use of Google Analytics on its website involved transfers of personal data to the U.S. without adequate safeguards, violating Article 44 GDPR. Despite SCCs and claimed supplementary measures (including IP anonymization), Google could access certain data in clear text and was subject to FISA 702; the DPA rejected a risk-based approach. Considering the tool was discontinued in January 2021, the DPA issued a reprimand.

noyb complained about telenor.com’s use of Google Analytics, and the Norwegian DPA’s preliminary conclusion found it breached GDPR transfer rules by transferring personal data outside the EEA. The case is cross-border; a draft decision will be shared with other DPAs under EDPB coordination after parties have three weeks to comment. The DPA advises exploring alternatives to Google Analytics and notes GA4 may not resolve the identified issues.

The Norwegian DPA fined EAS / Elektro & Automasjon Systemer AS for conducting a credit check on an individual without a valid legitimate interest and ordered improved internal routines under Article 24. It found negligence by the general manager, highlighted the sensitivity of credit data, and assessed GDPR Article 83(2) factors, noting cooperation and lack of prior violations. The fine was reduced to NOK 200,000 considering COVID-19 impacts while ensuring deterrence.

Appeal against the DPA’s rejection of a complaint seeking identities behind IP addresses used to access A’s Hotmail account. The Board held that Article 15 GDPR gives access only to the data subject’s own personal data and not to third parties’ identities, noting such data would be for ISPs and police via criminal procedure, not Microsoft. It concluded A had no right to further access under Article 15.

data.A14_EconomicSector: Code: 8411, Description: General public administration activities, Level: 4
data.A17_SensitiveDataTypes: Health, Racial_Ethnic, Political, Religious, Trade_Union, Sexual
data.A50_CaseSummary: A ransomware attack on Østre Toten municipality led to exfiltration and publication of large volumes of personal data, including special categories and children’s data, due to inadequate security measures (no 2FA, poor logging, unprotected backups). The Norwegian DPA found violations of Art. 32, Art. 24, and Art. 5(1)(f), imposed a NOK 4,000,000 fine, and ordered implementation of a management system with risk analyses. The DPA considered the municipality’s cooperation and remedial efforts as mitigating factors but emphasized the severity and scope of the breach.

data.A11_DefendantName: The Norwegian Labor and Welfare Administration (NAV)
data.A14_EconomicSector: Code: 8430, Description: Compulsory social security activities, Level: 4
data.A50_CaseSummary: NAV unlawfully published jobseekers’ CVs to employers without a valid legal basis since 2001, affecting up to 1.8 million individuals. The DPA found breaches of GDPR Articles 6(1), 6(3) and the principles of lawfulness and confidentiality in Article 5(1)(a),(f), noting negligence and a power imbalance. A fine of 5,000,000 NOK was imposed, with NAV’s remedial actions considered mitigating.

data.A11_DefendantName: The child protection service in X
data.A50_CaseSummary: A appealed the Norwegian DPA’s decision to close her complaint about alleged unlawful access and entries in her son’s child welfare record by the municipality of X. The Privacy Board found the matter outside the DPA’s competence under Article 57(1)(a), noting the State Administrator had already reviewed access logs and found no breach. The Board upheld the DPA’s rejection and took no further action.

The DPA found Recover AS conducted an unlawful credit assessment of a non-customer, lacking a legal basis under Art. 6(1)(f), breaching Art. 5(1)(a) and Art. 24. It established negligence by a project manager, identified inadequate internal routines, and systematically applied Art. 83(2) factors. A NOK 200,000 fine and an order to improve internal controls were imposed.

The Norwegian DPA banned the “Shinigami Eyes” browser extension’s processing of personal data for lacking a legal basis and failing to inform affected persons and users. The tool labels individuals online as pro- or anti-trans; legitimate interests was assessed and rejected due to risks to free expression and undisclosed labeling. The developer did not engage; the DPA will notify Google and Mozilla, and the developers have three weeks to appeal.

data.A14_EconomicSector: Code: 8030, Description: Investigation activities, Level: 4
data.A50_CaseSummary: A private investigation company performed a credit check on an individual without a valid legal basis; the DPA rejected legitimate interest under Art. 6(1)(f) and found a breach of the lawfulness principle in Art. 5(1)(a). It also found inadequate internal control under Art. 24 and ordered suitable routines, establishing negligence by top management; only one data subject was affected and the data were deleted during the investigation. The decision systematically applies Art. 83(2) factors and references EDPB/WP guidelines on fines.

The Estonian Data Protection Inspectorate terminated a supervision proceeding triggered by a Lithuanian citizen’s complaint alleging a GDPR breach linked to an authentication/signing app and a website notice about updating Android components. The entity stated it did not process the complainant’s data in the case, provided no QR codes, did not use the number 1394, and only advised users to update Google Chrome and Android System WebView after Google’s faulty update. The DPA found no GDPR violation and closed the case without sanctions.

The Norwegian DPA fined Argon NOK 2.5 million for notifying a personal data breach 67 days after becoming aware, far beyond the 72-hour Article 33(1) deadline. The breach involved unauthorized access to a spreadsheet with salary and benefits data of 20 European employees (one in Norway); no special-category data and no proven damage were found, but procedures to ensure prompt awareness and notification were inadequate. The DPA assessed Article 83(2) factors systematically, found negligence, and emphasized that initial notification should occur within 72 hours with phased updates if needed.

data.A14_EconomicSector: Code: 8411, Description: General public administration activities, Level: 4
data.A50_CaseSummary: The Norwegian DPA fined Lillestrøm municipality NOK 300,000 for breaching GDPR Art. 32(1)(b) after publishing a document where 10 of 21 attachments contained special-category data about students. The leak was detected by a journalist; four IPs accessed the document before it was removed and data subjects were notified. The fee was reduced from NOK 500,000 to NOK 300,000 considering the municipality’s routines and the human error explanation.

data.A14_EconomicSector: Code: 7310, Description: Advertising, Level: 4
data.A50_CaseSummary: The Norwegian DPA imposed urgent provisional measures banning Meta from processing personal data of data subjects in Norway for behavioural advertising based on Article 6(1)(b) or 6(1)(f). It found ongoing non-compliance with the Irish DPC’s decisions and the CJEU’s Bundeskartellamt ruling, violations of Article 6(1), improper handling of objections under Article 21, and transparency and data minimisation breaches. A temporary processing ban (4 August–3 November 2023) was ordered under Article 66(1), with compliance confirmation required by 4 August 2023.

Datatilsynet, acting as lead authority in a cross-border case, found Mowi ASA violated Article 14 by failing to inform shareholders when data were obtained from custodian banks, and noted a minor breach of Article 12(2) due to a delayed access response caused by spam filtering. It rejected reliance on Article 14(5)(a) and (c), highlighted misleading transparency in the privacy policy, and noted international transfers to the UK via SCCs. The DPA issued a reprimand and a compliance order to update transparency documentation and routines.

data.A14_EconomicSector: Code: 7010, Description: Activities of head offices, Level: 4
data.A50_CaseSummary: Datatilsynet investigated Telenor ASA’s DPO setup and internal controls after anonymous tips, treating it as a cross-border case with Norway as LSA. It found breaches of Articles 24(1)-(2), 38(3), 38(2) and a partial breach of 37(7), issuing compliance orders, a reprimand for lack of direct reporting to top management, and a NOK 4,000,000 fine. The DPA cited inadequate organisational measures, unclear roles/records, insufficient DPO resourcing and reporting, while noting no proven damage and some remedial steps.

data.A14_EconomicSector: Code: 8411, Description: General public administration activities, Level: 4
data.A50_CaseSummary: The DPA banned Statistics Norway from processing near-real-time grocery receipt/bank data from four chains for consumption and diet statistics due to lack of sufficient supplementary legal basis under Article 6(3) GDPR. It found the planned large-scale linkage to individuals a very significant privacy intrusion and criticized inadequate purpose definition and data minimization. No fine was imposed; the corrective measure was a processing ban under Article 58(2)(f).

data.A14_EconomicSector: Code: 8430, Description: Compulsory social security activities, Level: 4
data.A26_InfringementDuration: Many years, probably since establishment of NAV
data.A50_CaseSummary: The Norwegian DPA inspected NAV’s internal access control, logging, and governance, finding systemic failures in confidentiality and security under GDPR Articles 5, 24, and 32 affecting millions of data subjects. It notified orders to implement organizational and technical measures and an infringement fine of NOK 20 million, noting prior similar findings in 2007, 2010, and 2011 and characterizing the infringements as intentional. The reasoning relied on detailed Art. 83(2) factors, citing extensive, long-standing risks and highly sensitive data.

data.A14_EconomicSector: Code: 4729, Description: Other retail sale of food in specialized stores, Level: 4
data.A50_CaseSummary: The Norwegian DPA inspected Fast Candy AS after tips about employee-targeting camera and audio surveillance affecting mainly under-18 workers. It found lawful monitoring of the customer area for theft/safety, but ordered cessation of surveillance behind the till and in the back room, removal of all audio and remote access, improved employee information and signage, reduced retention, and establishment of internal controls. The DPA cited violations of GDPR Articles 6(1), 12, 13, and 24.

data.A14_EconomicSector: Code: 9492, Description: Activities of political organizations, Level: 4
data.A50_CaseSummary: The Norwegian DPA reprimanded Stavanger Arbeiderparti for sending targeted political emails to parents using addresses obtained from the municipality under access to information rules. It found inadequate balancing for legitimate interests under Art. 6(1)(f) and a breach of transparency duties under Art. 14; the municipal disclosure was lawful, only email addresses were processed, and deletion occurred promptly. Considering low risk and mitigating factors, the DPA issued a reprimand without a fine.

Datatilsynet issued a three-month temporary ban on Meta’s behavioral advertising in Norway based on GDPR Article 6(1)(b) and (f), invoking Article 66 emergency powers. The Oslo District Court rejected Meta’s request for a temporary injunction, noting ongoing cross‑border proceedings led by the DPC and finding no sufficient grounds for interim relief. A daily coercive fine of NOK 1,000,000 was imposed for non-compliance starting 14 August 2023.

data.A14_EconomicSector: Code: 8530, Description: Higher education, Level: 4
data.A50_CaseSummary: UiA stored documents with personal and health data in open Microsoft Teams folders without access control since 2018, lacked adequate logging, and had insufficient internal routines and training. The DPA found negligence and violations of Articles 24 and 32, noting exposure of employees, students, and refugees’ data, but acknowledged prompt notification and remediation. A NOK 150,000 administrative fine was imposed.

data.A14_EconomicSector: Code: 8430, Description: Social security administration, Level: 4
data.A50_CaseSummary: The Privacy Board overturned the DPA’s rejection for lateness, holding the delay excusable and confirming the DPA’s competence to handle Article 17 erasure requests. It then decided the merits, finding NAV’s continued storage lawful due to legal obligation and archival purposes in the public interest under GDPR Article 17(3)(b),(d) and Article 6(1)(e). A’s erasure request was therefore denied.

The Norwegian Privacy Board upheld the DPA’s decision that Getaround/Nabobil could lawfully conduct a credit assessment of a prospective renter under GDPR Article 6(1)(f). It found the processing necessary to mitigate financial risks such as deductibles, tolls, and other charges, and noted data minimization by limiting visibility of credit information. The appeal was rejected.

data.A14_EconomicSector: Code: 7310, Description: Advertising, Level: 4
data.A50_CaseSummary: OpenX appealed a Norwegian Data Protection Authority order to provide information, arguing that only the National Communications Authority had competence under the Electronic Communications Act for cookie-like technologies. The Privacy Board held that while ePrivacy rules cover storage/access on devices, GDPR still applies to subsequent processing and the DPA has authority under Articles 57 and 58 to demand information. The Board rejected the appeal and ordered OpenX to provide the requested report.

The case concerns X AS’s unlawful automatic forwarding and monitoring of an employee’s email for five weeks without a valid legal basis, failure to assess her objection, and lack of information. The DPA imposed a fine and an order to improve routines; on appeal, the Privacy Board upheld liability but reduced the fine from NOK 400,000 to NOK 250,000 due to excessive case processing time. The Board emphasized the seriousness of continuous email monitoring, including private emails, and considered Art. 83(2) factors.

data.A11_DefendantName: Child Protection Service in X municipality
data.A14_EconomicSector: Code: 8411, Description: General public administration activities, Level: 4
data.A50_CaseSummary: A appealed the Norwegian DPA’s refusal to order deletion of a note in his son’s child welfare record stating the father’s ethnic minority background. The Board held that archiving obligations and public-interest archival purposes under national law and GDPR Article 17(3)(b),(d) prevented deletion, and that the information was necessary to understand the case context. The DPA’s decision was upheld and the appeal was rejected.
